Derek, that's strange it looks like Edwin's website just went down.  
I'm g=
uessing it will come back up soon so that paper should become 
available.

=
Anyway, now I have a good grip of your proposed representation.  I 
believe=
 the following paper has a related multi-level encoding, 
although theirs m=
ay not be hierarchical.  But I think they do 
specify the layout at one lev=
el and more specific info at another:

Mandischer, M. (1993). Representatio=
n and evolution of neural 
networks. In Albrecht, R. F.,
Reeves, C. R., and=
 Steele, U. C., editors, Artificial Neural Nets 
and Genetic Algorithms, pa=
ges
643=96649, Springer Verlag, New York, New York.

It should be available=
 through Google.


ken

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Derek James" <djames@=
...> wrote:
>
> On 5/23/07, Kenneth Stanley <kstanley@...> wrote:
> 
>     =
I'm not completely sure of the mechanics of your cited
>     representation=
. When you say the "top leven gene specifies the
>     spatial layout ... o=
f the gene just below it," do you 
mean "gene" in
>     a singular sense? O=
r do you mean that a set of top-level genes 
that
>     specify a layout th=
at lower-level genes ahere to?
> 
> Sorry, yes, I meant the latter.  A modu=
le might be composed of 50-
100
> neurons, so the higher level module genes=
 would determine the 
layout and
> possibly connectivity of the lower level=
 neuron genes.
> 
>     De Jong, E.D., Richard A. Watson, and Dirk Thierens=
 (2005). On 
the
>     Complexity of Hierarchical Problem Solving. Proceedi=
ngs of the
>     Genetic and Evolutionary Computation Conference GECCO-05.
=
> 
>     That's from Edwin De Jong's page: http://www.cs.uu.nl/~dejong/
> 
=
>     Note that Richard Watson also did a lot of work on related 
topics
> =
    independently of Edwin De Jong.
> 
> That particular link is blocked to=
 me, but I was able to search 
around for
> related work, so thanks for the=
 pointer.
> 
> --Derek
